questions.text: A 28-year-old woman develops an acidophilic tumour of the pituitary. The tumour is likely to arise from which of the following cells of the anterior pituitary?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Lactotropes

Somatotropes and Lactotropes are the acidophilic cells in the anterior pituitary.

questions.text: A patient with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN I) and acromegaly is found to have deletion of the 11q13 region of chromosome 11, a suppressor gene for growth hormone. Which of the following is likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

insulin resistance
Patients with acromegaly have insulin resistance. In addition, they have increased lipolysis and increased gluconeogenesis due to their high growth hormone levels. The combination of enhanced glucose production and insulin resistance can produce hyperglycemia and diabetes mellitus.

choices.text: Fat content of gastric chyme duodenum
Acidity of gastric chyme in duodenum

questions.text: The rate of gastric emptying increases with an increase in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

intragastric volume
The initial rate of gastric emptying varies directly with the volume of the meal ingested. Increasing the volume, fat content, acidity, or osmolality of the gastric chyme in the lumen of the duodenum inhibits the gastric emptying.

choices.text: ADH increases water reabsorption from the ascending loop of Henle
Water reabsorption from the descending loop of Henle is normally less than that from the ascending loop of Henle
Sodium reabsorption from the ascending loop of Henle is normally less than that from the descending loop of Henle
Osmolarity of fluid in the early distal tubule would be less than 300 mOsm/l in a dehydrated person with normal kidneys and increased ADH levels

questions.text: Which statement is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

In a dehydrated person, osmolarity in the early distal tubule is usually less than 300 mOsm/l because the ascending limb of the loop of Henle and the early distal tubule are relatively impermeable to water, even in the presence of ADH. Therefore, the tubular fluid becomes progressively more dilute in these segments compared with plasma. ADH does not influence water reabsorption in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue and headaches. During the physical examination, he is found to have a wide pulse pressure. Which of the following conditions causes the pulse pressure to increase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hypertension
Pulse pressure is directly proportional to the stroke volume and inverse to the arterial compliance. 
Pulse pressure increases with hypertension because of a decrease in arterial compliance. 
Stroke volume is decreased in haemorrhage, aortic stenosis, and heart failure decreasing the pulse pressure in all three cases.

questions.text: A newborn with severe diarrhoea is found to have an inherited defect in a glucose transporter resulting in glucose/ galactose malabsorption, necessitating a glucose- and galactose- free diet. Which of the following is the transport protein responsible for entry of glucose onto the intestinal enterocyte?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

SGLT 1
The main transporter involved in glucose/galactose absorption in the intestine is the sodium- glucose co-transporter (SGLT 1).

questions.text: Parathormone increases calcium reabsorption in which of the following points along the nephron?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

DCT

PTH decreases inorganic phosphorus reabsorption in the PCT and increases calcium reabsorption in the DCT.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman has experienced dizziness for the past 6 months when getting out of bed in the morning and when standing up. Her mean arterial pressure is 130/90 mm Hg while lying down and 95/60 while sitting. Which set of physiological changes would be expected in response to moving from a supine to an upright position?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Moving from a supine to a standing position causes an acute fall in arterial pressure that is sensed by arterial baroreceptors located in the carotid sinuses and aortic arch. Activation of the baroreceptors results in a decrease in parasympathetic activity (or vagal tone) and an increase in sympathetic activity, which leads to an increase in plasma renin activity (or renin release).

choices.text: Increased intracellular chloride concentration, decreased cell volume
Increased intracellular chloride concentration, increased cell volume
Decreased intracellular chloride concentration, increased cell volume
Decreased intracellular chloride concentration, decreased cell volume

questions.text: Compared with arterial red blood cells, which of the following best describes the venous red blood cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Increased intracellular chloride concentration, increased cell volume

CO2 combines with water in the RBCs to form carbonic acid which dissociates into HCO3- and H+ ions. Bicarbonate diffuses out of the RBCs, whereas the chloride diffuses into the cells to maintain electrical neutrality. The phenomenon, called chloride shift occurs due to a special protein called AE-1 present in the RBC membrane that shuttles the ions in the opposite directions. Water moves into the RBCs to maintain osmotic equilibrium, which results in slight increase in size of the venous RBCs.

choices.text: A higher-than-normal flow of hypotonic urine
A higher-than-normal flow of hypertonic urine
A lower-than-normal flow of hypotonic urine
A lower-than-normal flow of hypertonic urine

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents with a 12-week history of frontal headaches. A CT scan of the brain shows a mass in the posterior pituitary, and the posterior pituitary “bright spot” is absent on MRI. The patient also complains of increased thirst and waking up frequently during the night. Which of the following best describes the urine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A higher-than-normal flow of hypotonic urine
The presence of a mass in the posterior pituitary coupled with presentation of thirst and nocturia, suggest that the patient has central diabetes insipidus with inadequate pituitary secretion of ADH. As a result of decreased ADH, the patient urine has a low tonicity.

questions.text: SCFA absorption occurs form which of the following segments of the GI tract?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Colon
Colonic bacteria act on dietary fibre, complex carbohydrates to produce SCFAs. SCFAs are produced in the colon and absorbed in the colon by specific transporters.

questions.text: The body fluid volume changes in a 34-year-old patient are shown below in Darrow-Yannet diagram (solid line – normal, dotted line – patient). Which of the following is the cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypotonic fluid loss causes increase in osmolarity and decrease in ECF Volume, it leads to shift of fluid from ICF to ECF till ICF osmolarity is same as ECF osmolarity.

choices.text: Opening of voltage gated sodium channels
Opening of long- lasting calcium channels

questions.text: The phases of the cardiac action potential are represented by the lettered points on the diagram below. Phase C is due to-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The plateau phase of the cardiac action potential is due to potassium efflux and a calcium influx through slow calcium channels (also k/a slow sodium- calcium channels).

questions.text: Both the peripheral and central chemoreceptors mediate increased ventilation in response to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hypercapnia
Both the peripheral and central chemoreceptors respond to an increase in Paco2 levels. The peripheral chemoreceptors also cause an increase in ventilation in response to a decrease in arterial pH and a decrease in Pao2. The central chemoreceptors are unresponsive to hypoxemia or to a decrease in arterial pH.

choices.text: Increasing the potassium permeability of the pre-synaptic nerve ending
Increasing the potassium permeability of the α-motor neuron
Hyperpolarizing the membrane potential of the α-motor neuron
Increasing the amount of neurotransmitter released by the pre-synaptic membrane

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis and increasing spasticity is treated with an intrathecal infusion of baclofen, a GABAB agonist which mediates pre-synaptic inhibition. Presynaptic inhibition in the CNS affects the firing rate of α-motor neurons by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Increasing the potassium permeability of the pre-synaptic nerve ending
Baclofen, a GABAB agonist, acting via a G-protein increases the potassium conductance, causing hyperpolarization of the pre-synaptic membrane, which in turn causes a pre-synaptic inhibition of the motor pathway, decreasing the spasticity.

questions.text: An 85-year-old man is waiting in the pre-op room where the air temperature is 21 degrees Celsius. He is wearing only a thin gown that is open at the back. Most of his body heat will be lost by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

radiation 
When the outside temperatures are lower than the body temperature, there is a tendency to lose heat. Major mechanism of heat loss will be radiation.

questions.text: If a person maintains a high (150 mmol/day) potassium diet, which part of the nephron would be expected to reabsorb the most potassium? Choose the appropriate nephron site in the figure below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Approximately 65% of the filtered load of potassium is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. Variations in renal excretion of potassium during change in potassium intake are achieved mainly by changes in potassium secretion in collecting tubules. With high potassium intake, the proximal tubule still reabsorbs a high fraction of the filtered load of potassium.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the Emergency with shortness of breath. His OHDC was shifted from that for normal hemoglobin A depicted in the curve A in the figure given below to curve B. this finding is consistent with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Recent transfusion with banked blood

In banked blood, glycolysis is inhibited which decreases the 2,3-BPG, shifting the OHDC to the left.

questions.text: Synaptic transmission between the pain fibres from the viscera in the pelvis to spinal cord neurons is mediated by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Substance P

The neurotransmitter secreted by C fibres for visceral pain is substance P.

choices.text: Plateau phase of the ventricular muscle action potential
Downstroke of the skeletal muscle action potential
Upstroke of the smooth muscle action potential
End-plate potential of the skeletal muscle fibre

questions.text: An increase in sodium conductance is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

End-plate potential of the skeletal muscle fibre
Binding of acetylcholine with its receptors on the motor end plate causes an increase in sodium conductance which in turn is responsible for the depolarizing motor end-plate potential.

choices.text: Excessive eating, rage and aggression, hyperactivity

questions.text: Bilateral lesions involving the lateral hypothalamus will lead to which of the following deficits?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

decreased eating and drinking

Lateral hypothalamus is the hunger, thirst, reward and pleasure center. Lesion of this area will lead to decreased eating and drinking. 
Lesions involving the ventromedial hypothalamus lead to excessive eating (hyperphagia), excessive drinking, rage and aggression, and hyperactivity.

choices.text: V/Q ratio of the left lung equals infinity
V/Q ratio of the left lung equals zero
Composition of the alveolar air in the left lung is similar to dead space air
Increase in left lung alveolar Po2

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is eating round candies approximately 1.5 cm in diameter. He accidentally inhales one down his airway, blocking his left main bronchus. Which of the following changes will occur in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

V/Q ratio of the left lung equals zero
When an airway is blocked (as in this case, by a foreign body), the ventilation on the affected side decreases to zero, and therefore, the V/Q ratio will be zero.  The air in the alveoli reaches an equilibrium with the pulmonary arterial blood. Therefore, the alveolar Po2 will decrease to 40 mm Hg, and the alveolar Pco2 increases to 45 mm Hg. Since the blood in the pulmonary capillaries gets “shunted” without getting oxygenated, the systemic arterial Po2 will decrease.

questions.text: Given below is a histology slide of the cerebellum- The cells shown in the slide project to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Deep nuclei.

questions.text: Which of the following points on the action potential is the driving force for Na+ the greatest?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The driving force for Na+ is greatest at the point at which Em is the farthest from E Na. If E Na is very positive (≈ 60 millivolts), Em is farthest from E Na at point D, or when the cell is the most hyperpolarized.

questions.text: The airway pressure of a normal 77-year-old man is approximately 1 cm H2O during expiration. What is his airway pressure during inspiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

-1 cm H2O

Expansion of the chest cavity during inspiration causes the airway pressure (also k/a intrapulmonary pressure or alveolar pressure) to become sub atmospheric, averaging about -1 cm H2O during quiet inspiration, resulting in movement of air into the lungs.

questions.text: A balloon catheter is advanced from the superior vena cava into the right atrium and inflated to increase the right atrial pressure by 5 mm Hg. An increase in which of the following would be expected to occur in response to the elevated atrial pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

ANP
Increase in RAP increases the secretion of ANP from the myocytes.

questions.text: When food is in the esophagus there is relaxation of the LES and fundus of the stomach. Which of the following is most likely to cause relaxation of the LES and fundus of the stomach during swallowing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

NO

During swallowing, the LES, fundus and upper part of the body of stomach relax and accommodate the food with very little increase in pressure.

This is k/a receptive relaxation (also k/a accommodation). Receptive relaxation is mediated by afferent and efferent fibres in the vagus and triggered by movement of the pharynx and esophagus. When the esophageal peristaltic wave approaches the stomach, a wave of relaxation, mediated by NO and VIP, precedes the peristalsis. 

Gastrin increases acid secretion in stomach.

Motilin mediates MMCs or housekeeping contractions between meals. 

NE can decrease smooth muscle contraction in the small intestine but is not involved in receptive relaxation.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy cuts his finger with a pocketknife and immediately applies pressure to the damaged area with his other hand to partially alleviate the pain. Inhibition of pain signals by tactile stimulation of the skin is mediated by which type of afferent neurons from mechanoreceptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Stimulation of β-type A fibers from peripheral tactile receptors can decrease transmission of pain signals by a type of lateral inhibition; this process is mediated by inhibitory interneurons in the dorsal column of the spinal cord. α-Type A neurons project to skeletal muscles, causing them to contract. δ-Type A fibers and type C fibers conduct pain signals to the dorsal column of the spinal cord.

questions.text: The graph given below depicts the relative filterability of glomerular filtration membrane of dextran molecules as a function of their molecular radius and electrical charges, 1 representing complete filtration and 0 representing no filtration. Which of the following are lines A, B and C respectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Polyanionic, neutral, polycationic

The graph shows that for any given molecular radius, cations are more readily filtered than anions because the negative charges on the sialoproteins of the basement membrane and podocytes tend to repel the large negatively charged molecules (polyanionic dextrans, curve A).

Large positively charged molecules (polycationic dextrans, curve C) are filtered more readily.

questions.text: Given in the diagram below are movements of the GI tract occurring at regular intervals during fasting and completely inhibited by a meal. These are -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

MMCs MMCs occur in the fasting state and occur in response to secretion of a hormone, Motilin by the M cells in the small intestine. They begin as a ring of contraction in the body of stomach and migrate up to the distal ileum. Their function is a clearing action. First MMC occurs 90-120 minutes after the last meal and then occur every 90 minutes. Each MMC has three phases- phase I is the quiescent phase, phase II is the phase of irregular electrical and motor activity, phase III is the phase of regular electrical and motor activity. The three phases take 90 minutes for completion. The rate of propagation of MMC is very slow- 5 cm/min.

questions.text: Increase in which of the following neurotransmitters is associated with sleep?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

GABA

Increase in GABA and decrease in Histamine promote NREM sleep via deactivation of the thalamus and cortex.

questions.text: Increases in both renal blood flow and GFR are caused by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dilatation of the afferent arterioles

Dilatation of the afferent arterioles will increase both the renal blood flow and GFR. Dilatation of the efferent arteriole will cause an increase in renal blood flow but decrease the GFR.

choices.text: Dorsal horn of the spinal cord
Ventral horn of the spinal cord

questions.text: Enkephalinergic interneurons that are most likely to inhibit afferent pain signals are most likely to be found in which of the following regions of the central nervous system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

dorsal horn of the spinal cord
Enkephalinergic interneurons in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord cause a pre-synaptic and post-synaptic inhibition of the pain pathway decreasing pain transmission.

questions.text: Which of the following is higher at the apex of the lung than at the base when a person is upright?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

V/Q ratio

Ventilation and blood flow are more at the base during standing but the V/Q ratio is maximum at apex. Pao2 is maximum and Paco2 is the minimum at the apex.

choices.text: CO2 activation of the carotid bodies
Hydrogen ion (H+) activation of the carotid bodies
CO2 activation of the chemosensitive area of the medulla
H+ activation of the chemosensitive area of the medulla

questions.text: What is the most important pathway for the respiratory response to systemic arterial PCO2?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

CO2 is the major controller of respiration because of a direct effect of H+ on the chemosensitive area of the medulla. H+ do not cross the blood-brain barrier. Thus, CO2 diffuses across the blood-brain barrier and then is converted to H+, which acts on the chemo sensitive area. CO2 and H+ activation of carotid bodies is minimal under normal conditions.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is standing on a six feet high wall and suddenly jumps off landing on the balls of his feet. The increase in muscle tension causes a sudden, complete relaxation of the affected muscles. Which of the following receptors are responsible for reflex relaxation of the muscles when tension is increased?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Golgi tendon organ

The Golgi tendon organ senses the tension in the tendons. When the tension becomes exceedingly high, a bi-synaptic inhibitory reflex is activated that causes relaxation of the entire muscle, which protects the muscle from tearing and from avulsion of tendon. The centre for this reflex is the spinal cord and the efferent arm of this reflex is the Aα motor neurons.

choices.text: Maximum and minimum left ventricular pressures are virtually the same as systolic and diastolic pressures measured in a peripheral artery.
> 90% of the end-diastolic volume is ejected.
Left ventricular pressure is greater than left atrial pressure at all stages of the cycle.
The mitral valve is open longer than is the aortic valve

questions.text: Which of the following is true in a normal cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Diastole is longer in duration than systole.

questions.text: What is the calculated vascular resistance to blood flow through the kidneys from the following data? Systolic arterial pressure = 130 mm Hg, diastolic arterial pressure = 70 mm Hg, mean renal venous pressure = 10 mm Hg, renal blood flow = 800 mL/min, renal arterial compliance = 4 mL/mm Hg.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

MAP = DBP + 1/3 PP = 70 + 1/3(60) = 90 mmHg 

So, R = MAP- Mean Renal Venous Pressure / Flow   =   90-10= 80 mmHg / 800mL/min 

= 0.1 mm Hg/mL/min.

choices.text: Transport of glucose from the intestinal lumen into intestinal epithelial cell is by secondary active co-transport
Transport of glucose into adipocytes is by facilitated diffusion
Movement of Ca++ from cardiac muscle cell to the ECF during muscle relaxation is by Na+-dependent counter transport
Movement of Na++ ions into a nerve cell during the upstroke phase of the action potential is by facilitated diffusion

questions.text: Given below are four examples of transport across the cell membrane with the type of transport. Which of the following is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Absorption of glucose from the intestinal lumen into the intestinal epithelial cells is by Na+- glucose co-transport, an example of secondary active co-transport. 
Glucose is transported into adipocytes by insulin-dependent facilitated diffusion. 
Movement of Ca++ from cardiac muscle cell to the ECF during muscle relaxation is by Na+-Ca++ antiport, which is an example of secondary active counter transport. 
During the depolarization phase of the action potential opening of voltage gated sodium channels

questions.text: In the steady state, which of the following is higher in ICF?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Number of osmoles

The osmolality of the ICF and ECF is the same. In a healthy adult, the ICF volume is twice as large as the ECF volume. The absolute number of osmoles will, therefore, be higher in the ICF.

choices.text: It produces its effect by activating cAMP
It produces its effect by increasing the distal tubular permeability to sodium
It causes an increased secretion of hydrogen ions
It is secreted in response to decrease in blood pressure

questions.text: All except the following characterize the production and actions of aldosterone in the body-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aldosterone binds to an intracytoplasmic receptor that causes an increased synthesis of proteins, including the Na+- K+ ATPase pumps, ENaCs, K+ channels, which together increase the sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion by the tubular cells of the distal nephron. Aldosterone also increases the H+ secretion in the distal nephron. Aldosterone secretion is stimulated by a decrease in blood volume (through the renin- angiotensin system) and by an increased plasma K+ concentration.

choices.text: Impaired pre-synaptic voltage sensitive calcium influx
Inhibition of calcium uptake into the sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: A 50-year-old man visits the neurophysician because of weakness in his legs that improves during the course of the day. Extracellular electrical recordings from a single muscle fibre reveal normal miniature end plate potentials. Low frequency electrical stimulation of the motor neuron, however, elicits an abnormally small depolarization of the muscle fibres. The amplitude of depolarization is increased after exercise. Which of the following is most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Impaired pre-synaptic voltage sensitive calcium influx

Weakness that improves during the course of the day is typically seen in Lambert-Eaton syndrome. Patients with LES have antibodies against the voltage-gated calcium channels on the pre-synaptic membrane.

questions.text: In addition to increasing the permeability of the collecting ducts to water, ADH increases the permeability of the collecting ducts to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Urea

ADH increases the permeability of the collecting ducts to water and urea. The increased urea permeability increases the urea concentration and osmolality of the medullary interstitial fluid surrounding the loop of henle and the distal nephron.

questions.text: Vibratory sensation depends on the detection of rapidly changing, repetitive sensations. The low-frequency end of the repetitive stimulation scale is detected by which structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Low-frequency repetitive stimulation (indentation/pressure) of the skin is sensed by Meissner corpuscles.

choices.text: Blood pressure and heart rate increase
Blood pressure and heart rate decrease
Blood pressure increases and heart rate decreases
Blood pressure decreases and heart rate increases

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has a fall from his cycle and sustains a skull fracture which compresses the underlying brain tissue. Which of the following will occur in response to an increased intracranial pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Blood pressure increases and heart rate decreases

Increase in intracranial pressure decreases cerebral blood flow producing CNS ischemia. This in turn increase sympathetic discharge increasing the blood pressure. Increased blood pressure stimulates the baroreceptors producing a reflex bradycardia.

questions.text: A normal 20-year-old male breathes in as much air as he can and then exhales as much air as possible. The lung volume at maximum inspiration is 6.0L, and the lung volume after maximum expiration is 1.0L. His tidal volume at rest is 0.5L, and his functional residual capacity is 3.5L. What is his vital capacity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

5.0L

Forced vital capacity or vital capacity is the volume of air expired forcefully after a forceful inspiration. FVC = TLC – RV = 6.0 – 1.0 = 5.0L.

choices.text: Myosin head detachment from the actin molecule
Displacement of tropomyosin exposing the active sites on actin

questions.text: As part of an experiment, radiolabeled ATP is injected into the skeletal muscle. During muscle contraction, the labeled ATP is observed to attach to the sarcomere. This attachment causes immediate:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Myosin head detachment from the actin molecule. In actin- myosin cross- bridge cycling attachment of ATP causes an immediate detachment of head. Calcium binding to troponin-C, causes a conformational change in troponin which causes displacement of tropomyosin exposing the active sites on actin and resulting in actin- myosin cross bridge formation.

choices.text: Most control systems of the body act by negative feedback
Positive feedback usually promotes stability in a system.
Generation of nerve actions potentials involves positive feedback.
Feed-forward control is important in receptive relaxation of stomach.

questions.text: Which statement about feedback control systems is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Positive feedback usually promotes stability in a system

Positive feedback in a system generally promotes instability, rather than stability, and in some cases even death. For this reason, positive feedback is often called a “vicious cycle.” However, in some instances, positive feedback can be useful. One example is the nerve action potential where stimulation of the nerve membrane causes a slight leakage of sodium that causes more opening of sodium channels, more change of potential, and more opening of channels until an explosion of sodium entering the interior of the nerve fiber creates the action potential. Feed-forward control is used to apprise the brain whether a muscle movement is performed correctly. If not, the brain corrects the feed-forward signals that it sends to the muscles the next time the movement is required. This mechanism is often called adaptive control.

questions.text: Listed below are the hydrostatic and oncotic pressures within a microcirculatory bed. Plasma colloid osmotic pressure = 25 mm Hg Capillary hydrostatic pressure = 25 mm Hg Venous hydrostatic pressure = 5 mm Hg Arterial pressure = 80 mm Hg Interstitial fluid hydrostatic pressure = −5 mm Hg Interstitial colloid osmotic pressure = 10 mm Hg Capillary filtration rate = 150 ml/min What is the net filtration pressure (mm Hg)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

15

The capillary filtration coefficient is calculated as rate of net fluid movement across a capillary wall divided by net filtration pressure. Net filtration pressure = capillary hydrostatic pressure − plasma colloid osmotic pressure + interstitial colloid osmotic pressure − interstitial hydrostatic pressure. Net filtration pressure is [Pc − Πc + Πi − PI ] = [25 − 25 + 10 − (−5)] 15 mm Hg.

questions.text: Assuming that vessels A to D are the same length, which one has the greatest flow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The flow in a vessel is directly proportional to the pressure gradient across the vessel and to the fourth power of the radius of the vessel. In contrast, blood flow is inversely proportional to the viscosity of the blood. Because blood flow is proportional to the fourth power of the vessel radius, the vessel with the largest radius (vessel D) would have the greatest flow.
